description: From Middle English drake (“male duck, drake”), from Old English *draca, abbreviated form for Old English *andraca (“male duck, drake”, literally “duck-king”), from Proto-West Germanic *anadrekō (“duck leader”). Cognate with Low German drake (“drake”), Dutch draak (“drake”), German Enterich (“drake”). More at ennet.

From Middle English drake (“dragon; Satan”), from Old English draca (“dragon, sea monster, huge serpent”), from Proto-West Germanic *drakō (“dragon”), from Latin dracō (“dragon”), from Ancient Greek δράκων (drákōn, “serpent, giant seafish”), from δέρκομαι (dérkomai, “I see clearly”), from Proto-Indo-European *derḱ-. Compare Middle Dutch drake and German Drache. Doublet of dragon.

entries.meaning: A mayfly used as fishing bait.

examples: Clay caught sight of the drake's wing outlined against the rising flames as it swept low over the desert.
The moon’s my constant Mistresse& the lowlie owle my morrowe.The flaming Drake and yͤ Nightcrowe makemee musicke to my sorrowe.

entries.meaning: A beaked galley, or Viking warship.
